content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A well defined, structured, and creative clash!

This is an example of a solution that passes all tests but not validator 3, please consider adding some more tests (ruby):

n = gets.to_i
all = ""
xs = []
rest = []
n.times do |i|
  _line = gets
  all += _line
  line = _line.chomp.split
  if i == 0
    xs += line
  elsif i < n - 1
    xs << line.pop
    rest << line.shift
  else
    xs += line.reverse
  end
end
xs += rest.reverse
k = xs.each_cons(2).map { |x, y| y.to_i - x.to_i }.tally.max_by { _2 }[0]
i = xs.index("XX")
# xs[i] = "%02d" % (i > 0 ? xs[i-1].to_i + k : xs[i+1] - k)

puts all.gsub(/XX/, "%02d" % (i > 0 ? xs[i-1].to_i + k : xs[i+1] - k))

All in all, I like the clash but I think this may be a bit too long.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem seems to be well structured, with a clear set of test cases and validators

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Definitely a more difficult puzzle, but very manageable with experience

Learning about arithmetic sequences in math class so it was fun to actually do something with the stuff we learned.

I managed to pass all of the cases + validators, except test case 4. I believe you have a small typo when making the test case. It should go up by 3 per term, but it went 28 -> 33. (The reason your solution passes all the test cases seems to be because of integer division)

Fun clash.
I would suggest to modify the input and output comments in the program instead of some strings. Hope this helps
Thanks for the reply. Do you think that, ignoring the input and output text, this clash would work as reverse?

Whoops, I had created the cases just 'by hand', so apparently I took one step of 5 instead of 3 over there. I think my solution works because I recreate a range and check which of those numbers is not in the input, and then simply take the first missing (assuming all others are there anyway). For test 4 the XX was before the mistake, so that one was the first one missing from the range. So I passed a bit luckily - if XX would be after the mistake my code would have failed. I am glad your code did fail --> thanks for finding the mistake!
I corrected the mistake.

Thanks. FYI, based on Rafarafa's comment I pull this contribution in WIP until I have time to add one or two more cases so that code does not pass tests but not all validators. When it's back, hopefully you will approve again :-).

Thanks. FYI, based on Rafarafa's comment I pull this contribution in WIP until I have time to add one or two more cases so that code does not pass tests but not all validators. When it's back, hopefully you will approve again :-).

Thanks for pointing out this edge case! I'll pull it back in WIP until I added cases to let a person fail either both tests&validators or succeed in all.
I agree it is on the long side - I was curious how the community would think about it. I did deliberately put the XX in so that it is 'simply' a matter of getting and sorting all numbers, finding the missing one, and putting it at position XX. I think that such awareness + coding should be possible in 5 minutes for the faster coders.

Ok, it's back, with two changes:
- I simply copied test/validator 3, and put them in as validator/test 4. I did not get to the depth of why your solution failed only validator 3 (I don't know Ruby and also did not try hard enough), but at least now your code fails also a Test.
- To skim a bit of required solving time I have removed any number <10, so during playing this clash you do not have to worry about returning 9 as 09 anymore (only two digit numbers without leading zeroes are used and required).
Sounds good! I'll make sure to keep an eye out for it

I see your approval is simply kept in place. I made two changes (added a test/validator case and made the clash slightly easier by removing any value <10), I've explained them in a reply to Rafarafa's comment. I hope your approval is still valid :-).
